questionList.questionText: A 25-year-old man is evaluated in the hospital after telling the nurse he needs to leave now.  The patient was admitted earlier today with fever and pleuritic chest pain.  Initial chest x-ray reveals several nodular cavitary lesions.  He is being treated with intravenous vancomycin.  Medical history is significant for opioid use disorder.  On examination, the patient appears mildly anxious but mental status is normal.  Temperature is 37.8 C (100 F), blood pressure is 118/74 mm Hg, pulse is 92/min and regular, and respirations are 18/min.  On auscultation, lungs have bibasilar crackles and there is a 2/6 holosystolic murmur at the apex.  Skin examination shows several track marks in the left antecubital fossa but no diaphoresis or piloerection.  Pupils and neurologic examination are normal.  Leukocyte count is 14,800/mm3.  Blood cultures, echocardiogram, and chest CT are pending.  After the physician clearly informs the patient of the risks to his health posed by leaving before his treatment is complete, he says, "I'm sorry doc, I know how serious this is and that I need IV antibiotics or I could die, but I have to leave right now to take care of some things.  Can I get some antibiotic pills and come back in a couple of days?"  Which of the following is the best response to this patient's question?
questionList.explanationText:
Management of AMA discharges

Investigate/address
reasons for leaving

  • Financial concerns: involve social workers
  • Substance withdrawal: offer medication-assisted treatment
  • Care delay dissatisfaction: apologize for unmet expectations

Ensure/document patient's
informed refusal

  • Determine that patient:
    • Has capacity for medical decision-making
    • Understands benefits of staying & risks of leaving
    • Communicates reasoned basis for refusing treatment
  • Document informed refusal in chart, including signed AMA form

Provide best possible
alternative treatment

  • Offer appropriate treatments/prescriptions
  • Offer assistance with follow-up care
  • Offer to resume treatment at any time

AMA = against medical advice.

This patient likely has right-sided infective endocarditis (IE) with septic pulmonary emboli acquired through injection drug use.  Standard of care is prolonged (eg, weeks), parenteral, culture-directed antibiotics.  However, this patient requests discharge against medical advice (AMA) before evaluation is complete.

AMA encounters raise an ethical dilemma between a patient's autonomy to make treatment-related decisions and a physician's obligation of beneficence to promote patient welfare.  The principle of beneficence makes preventing AMA discharge the overriding goal because incomplete treatment increases risks of readmission, morbidity, and mortality.

Prevention begins with investigating the patient's reasons for leaving and attempting to address these concerns empathically (eg, "I want what's best for you … I may be able to help") so inpatient treatment can continue.  The most common reasons can often be anticipated and addressed with open communication and resource utilization.  Examples include:

  • Further educating patients about their care plan when frustrated with prolonged length of stay
  • Involving social workers for patients with financial concerns/caregiver responsibilities
  • Apologizing for any care delays that may have occurred (apologies are free; lawsuits are expensive)
  • Investigating withdrawal concerns/symptoms for patients with substance use disorder

Directly asking about substance use and withdrawal fears in a nonjudgmental, nonconfrontional manner may help patients express their concerns openly.  In patients with opioid use disorder who are actively using (eg, track marks in this patient with IE), prescribing methadone can reduce the probability of AMA discharge by 50% and risk of overdose by 75% at 1 year.

(Choices A, C, D, and E)  When good-faith efforts fail to prevent discharge, the patient's wishes should be respected.  Beneficence warrants offering the best possible alternative care plan, even if nonstandard (eg, empiric antibiotics prior to culture results).  Whenever possible, patients should be offered the same prescriptions and follow-up as during planned/formal discharge, without coercion (ie, withholding antibiotics unless an AMA form is signed).  Physicians should document patients' capacity to make decisions and understanding of the potential risks of leaving in the chart as an informed refusal (similar to informed consent) and should ask patients to sign an AMA form.  However, AMA forms do not preclude offering the best possible alternative care and cannot substitute for the legal protection provided by clear documentation of good-faith attempts at prevention and follow-up.

Educational objective:
Prematurely discontinuing treatment (ie, leaving against medical advice) increases risks of patient readmission and mortality.  Often, this is preventable by understanding patients' reasons for leaving and addressing their concerns.  When prevention fails, physicians should continue to act with beneficence, including offering the best alternative treatment available.

questionList.questionText: A 77-year-old woman is admitted to the intensive care unit due to pneumonia.  She has a history of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis that has progressively worsened over the past 2 years with increasing weight loss, weakness, fatigue, and dependence on supplemental oxygen.  Her life expectancy is <6 months.  The patient is alert and oriented.  The attending physician examines her and explains that appropriate antibiotics will be administered to treat pneumonia.  After reviewing the patient's medical record, the physician believes that a do-not-resuscitate order may be appropriate and prepares to initiate discussion with her regarding code status.  Which of the following statements is most appropriate?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient is being hospitalized for acute pneumonia in the context of severe, progressive pulmonary disease.  Her prognosis is poor, and there is a significant likelihood that she may experience cardiorespiratory failure during the hospitalization.  Her preferences for resuscitative measures should be discussed candidly because she may wish to avoid intubation and mechanical ventilation.

Patients commonly fear that a do-not-resuscitate order may relegate them to a lower priority for the care team or otherwise compromise their care.  To promote alignment of this patient's preferences with her code status, she should be reassured that her decisions regarding code status will not otherwise alter the treatment or overall quality of care she receives.

In addition, discussion regarding resuscitation preferences should include the following characteristics:

  • Address code status in the context of a broader discussion of the patient's goals of care.

  • Present resuscitation as a comprehensive intervention:  Addressing resuscitation measures "a-la-carte" (ie, one at a time) removes the focus from overall goals and may lead to confusion for the patient and care team.

  • Use neutral terminology and avoid leading questions that may direct a patient away from expressing their true preferences:  For example, a patient may find it difficult to decline services that are euphemistically framed as mechanisms to "keep you alive," "keep you from dying," or "help you live longer."  Conversely, phrases such as "drastic/artificial measures," "tubes and machines," and "pushing on your chest" may carry negative connotations that are difficult for a patient to accept (Choices A, B, and D).

Educational objective:
Patients often fear that a do-not-resuscitate order may relegate them to a lower priority for the care team or otherwise compromise their care.  To best understand the patients' wishes, code status should be addressed in a broader discussion regarding goals of care, using nonleading questions, avoiding euphemisms, and providing reassurance that their decisions will not otherwise alter their treatment or overall quality of care.

questionList.questionText: A 62-year-old woman with a history of multiple medical conditions, including coronary artery disease, hypertension, and osteoarthritis, arrives by ambulance at the emergency department after tripping and falling down the stairs.  The patient is currently on vacation with friends and new to the hospital system, with no history available in the electronic medical record.  Blood pressure is 170/105 mm Hg and pulse is 75/min.  She is alert, fully oriented and conversant, but in severe pain.  X-ray reveals a fracture of the right hip necessitating emergency surgical repair.  As the patient is admitted to the hospital, the nurse prepares to create a list of the patient's home medications in the electronic medical record.  Of the following practices, which is likely most effective in reducing errors related to medication reconciliation during this patient's hospitalization?
questionList.explanationText:
Preventable adverse drug events

Risk factors

Sample corrective strategies

Patient

  • Polypharmacy
  • Low health literacy
  • Very young or advanced age
  • Communication barriers
  • Nonadherence/lack of follow-up
  • Increased checkpoints in medication reconciliation (eg, multiple providers)
  • Plain-language medication counseling
  • Patient "teach-back" (ie, patient describes understanding of treatment in own words)

Provider

  • Vague prescriptions
  • Incorrect medication reconciliation
  • Absence of counseling
  • Illegible handwriting

Medication

  • Look- or sound-alike drugs (eg, prednisone/prednisolone)

Errors in medication reconciliation (ie, the process of reviewing and updating a patient's medication regimen) occur frequently during transfer of care (eg, hospital admission).  Errors include omitting active medications; including outdated prescriptions; and recording an incorrect dose, form, route, or frequency.

To prevent errors, multiple care team members should verify medications independently with the patient.  This technique represents redundancy, a safety strategy used to reduce errors in complex, high-risk organizations (eg, health care, aviation).

Medication reconciliation should always involve direct conversation with the patient (when cognitively intact), address both prescription and nonprescription medications (including supplements), and include inspection of medication bottles if available.  Other best practices for medication reconciliation include the following:

  • Interprofessional review, including physicians, nurses, and pharmacists; each provider should review medications independently with the patient

  • Brief, updated review by the ordering physician prior to placing or renewing medication orders

(Choice A)  Contacting family members may be appropriate in certain cases (eg, cognitively impaired patient).  This patient is fully oriented; therefore, reconciliation should first be performed with the patient.

(Choice B)  The patient's pharmacy can be contacted for additional verification; however, this should not substitute for direct conversation with the patient.  Pharmacy records may not accurately reflect how the patient is actually taking medications or her concomitant use of nonprescription medications.

(Choice C)  Limiting medication reconciliation to only designated nursing staff reduces the number of opportunities to catch mistakes and increases the risk of error.  All nursing staff should be trained in medication reconciliation and encouraged to reconcile patient medications when appropriate.

(Choice D)  Certain medications (eg, insulin, beta blockers) are considered high risk due to the potential for serious adverse effects.  However, many medications that are considered low risk (including over-the-counter medications) can cause serious complications directly or indirectly by interacting with other medications.  Therefore, all medications should be carefully included in reconciliation.

Educational objective:
Errors in medication reconciliation (ie, the process of reviewing and updating the current medication regimen) occur frequently during the transfer of care.  Prevention includes independent review by multiple care team members, interprofessional review (eg, physicians, nurses, pharmacists), and updated review prior to medication orders.

questionList.questionText: A 13-year-old child and the child's mother come to a busy primary care clinic for a new patient appointment.  The child was assigned male at birth but identifies as female.  When scheduling the appointment 3 weeks earlier, the mother provided the child's demographic information, including legal name and sex, and informed the medical assistant of the child's preferred name.  The medical assistant recorded and sent this information to the pediatrician via a secured message in the clinic's electronic medical record.  On the day of the appointment, a different medical assistant calls the child in from the waiting room but uses the incorrect name.  Which of the following is most recommended to reduce future likelihood of this error?
questionList.explanationText:
Human factors engineering strategies

Reliability

Strategy

Description & examples

Highest

Forcing functions

  • Hard stops in design or process to eliminate risk for incorrect use
  • Example: each anesthesia gas fits only one compatible socket & is not interchangeable

Computerized automation

  • Automated processes to remove human effort & variations that cause error
  • Example: automated vital signs monitoring

Environment & physical layout

  • Workspace design to facilitate correct action & minimize error
  • Example: look-alike drugs stocked in different locations

High

Standardization & simplification

  • Uniform processes to minimize variation, complexity & learning curve
  • Example: every hospital unit follows the same process for heparin administration

Human-machine redundancy

  • Repetitive step to confirm correct action in an error-prone process
  • Example: barcode scanning of medications in addition to visual inspection

Medium

Reminders, alerts & double-checks

  • Processes prompting providers to check actions to reduce errors
  • Examples: drug-drug interaction alerts; time-out before procedures

HFE seeks to reduce error risk by designing systems based on expected human behaviors.  Less reliable HFE strategies include training, policy changes & education.

HFE = human factors engineering.

Transgender patients are more likely to experience inadequate health care access and discrimination (eg, providers unfamiliar with transgender health needs or refusing to see patients).  As seen in this case, transgender patients frequently experience communication errors (eg, addressed as the incorrect pronoun or name), which increase emotional distress and reluctance to seek medical care.  This patient's preferred name was communicated in advance but overlooked, reflecting human error (increased in busy settings).

Such errors often reflect system-level deficiencies (eg, poor teamwork, inefficient workflow) rather than individual negligence.  Human factors engineering (HFE) strategies decrease human effort (eg, reliance on memory) to facilitate correct action.  This communication error could most effectively be prevented by redesigning physical systems, including improving visibility of key patient information.  Examples include placing preferred name and gender in bold text as a chart header, or creating an electronic alert with the preferred name when the chart is accessed.  This strategy simplifies accurate communication by highlighting important information and reducing manual effort (eg, checking prior documentation, reviewing demographic information).

(Choice A)  Although policies promoting equitable transgender care are necessary, addressing all patients by their last name only (eg, "Smith" rather than "John Smith") to avoid using incorrect names or honorifics (eg, "Mr.," "Ms.") risks overlooking individual patient preferences, particularly with pediatric patients.

(Choice B)  Duplicate charts should not be created due to safety concerns (eg, incomplete charts, conflicting information between charts).

(Choice C)  Redundancy (ie, multiple staff reviewing charts) can reduce errors, but it is likely impractical in this busy setting and less effective than physical redesign because it relies on additional human effort.

(Choice E)  Provider education and training are essential to reducing health care disparities.  However, they are comparatively less effective HFE strategies and are ideally combined with highly effective physical approaches.  Furthermore, education should be interdisciplinary (eg, including different professions) rather than physician-focused because transgender patient interactions involve multiple staff (eg, medical assistant).

Educational objective:
Transgender patients experience significant health disparities, including communication errors (eg, addressed as incorrect name/pronoun), that increase emotional distress and reluctance to seek care.  Such errors can be prevented by human factors engineering strategies incorporating physical changes (eg, visibility of patient preferred name/gender in the chart) and simplification, which reduce the effort needed for correct action.

questionList.questionText: An 8-month-old, previously healthy girl is hospitalized in the pediatric intensive care unit for septic shock due to meningococcemia.  A right internal jugular central venous catheter is placed for hemodynamic monitoring and vasopressor administration.  The patient receives appropriate antibiotics; her clinical condition improves, and daily laboratory results, including complete blood count, electrolytes, and glomerular filtration rate, return to normal.  On hospital day 4, after a dressing change and catheter inspection, a provider flushes the catheter with low-dose heparin for routine catheter maintenance.  Seconds later, the patient becomes cyanotic and tachypneic.  Blood pressure is 70/40 mm Hg, pulse is 140/min, and respirations are 70/min.  Oxygen saturation is 93% on 100% nonrebreather oxygen mask.  Pulmonary examination shows tachypnea with normal breath sounds.  Pupils are equal and reactive to light.  Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's presentation?
questionList.explanationText:
This infant developed hypoxia, hypotension, and tachypnea immediately following "flushing" (ie, injecting a small volume of low-concentration heparin or saline, done to prevent catheter occlusion) of her central venous catheter (CVC).  The most likely cause is pulmonary embolism due to catheter-related thrombus, as suggested by the following:

  • Presence of a CVC, which is the leading risk factor for venous thromboembolism (VTE) in children.  CVCs are thrombogenic because they introduce foreign material (triggering the coagulation cascade), interfere with blood flow, and cause intravascular micro-trauma.

  • Sudden symptom onset following CVC manipulation (eg, removal, flushing, repositioning), which dislodges the thrombus (eg, formed at catheter tip) into systemic circulation and the lungs.

  • Meningococcemia, which results in hypercoagulability due to activated protein C deficiency.

In children, pulmonary embolism presentations may be classic, as in this patient (eg, tachypnea, hypoxia, hypotension), or nonspecific.  A high index of suspicion for VTE should be maintained when children with indwelling CVCs experience acute, unexpected clinical deterioration, especially after CVC manipulation.  Heparin flushes and deep venous thrombosis prophylaxis (eg, with subcutaneous low molecular weight heparin) do not prevent catheter-related thrombus; insufficient evidence currently exists for use of systemic anticoagulation (eg, with therapeutic doses) to prevent VTE in children with CVCs.

(Choice A)  Bacteremia from access site infection can cause hypotension and tachycardia; however, this patient's sudden hypoxia following catheter mobilization makes VTE more likely.

(Choice B)  Incorrect CVC placement (eg, tip in bronchus) can manifest with acute pulmonary edema, presenting as  hypotension, hypoxia, and tachycardia, immediately following initial CVC use.  Acute pulmonary edema is unlikely in this patient whose catheter was used for several days without incident.

(Choice C)  Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia can manifest with systemic thrombus; however, this patient lacks thrombocytopenia (ie, normal recent complete blood count).  Anaphylaxis can result in sudden-onset tachypnea and hypotension but would more likely be associated with bronchospasm (ie, wheezing vs normal breath sounds) and urticaria.  In addition, the patient's symptom proximity to catheter manipulation makes catheter-related VTE more likely.

(Choice D)  Incorrect heparin administration (eg, accidentally using high- rather than low-concentration heparin to flush CVC catheters) can result in immediate, catastrophic cerebral hemorrhage.  This patient lacks signs of cerebral hemorrhage (eg, seizures, vomiting, abnormal pupillary findings) and systemic bleeding (eg, from catheter site).  Her sudden tachypnea and hypoxia suggest a pulmonary etiology for her symptoms.

Educational objective:
Central venous catheters are the leading risk factor for thromboembolic events in children; thromboembolism should be suspected when acute hypoxia and hypotension develop following central line manipulation (eg, removal, catheter flushing).  Thromboemoblism risk increases with underlying hypercoagulability (eg, meningococcemia).

questionList.questionText: A team of hospital administrators is concerned about very low rates of staff compliance with recommended hand hygiene protocols.  Staff follow hand hygiene protocols less than 30% of the time; the team believes low compliance is a primary factor behind the hospital's higher-than-average rate of preventable nosocomial infections.  Multiple interventions are implemented to increase compliance, including placing signage in all high-traffic areas to remind staff to clean hands regularly, and holding staff training sessions that reinforce current evidence for hand hygiene and infection prevention.  Based on staff feedback and input, additional handwashing stations with sinks and alcohol-based gel dispensers are installed inside and outside most patient rooms to optimize access to hand hygiene materials.  Staff are informed that their hand hygiene practices will be regularly monitored and tracked.  After several months of implementing these changes, video surveillance indicates that staff hand hygiene compliance has improved to only 70%, with minimal variance in compliance rates among hospital units.  Additional interventions targeting which of the following areas are recommended to further improve this problem?
questionList.explanationText:
Improving hand hygiene compliance in health care settings

Reason for noncompliance

Example solution

Ineffective placement
of sinks & dispensers

Place sinks/dispensers outside each patient's room

Lack of accountability

Build hand hygiene into provider evaluations

Lack of safety culture

Create safety teams, provide real-time feedback on compliance

Forgetfulness or lack of time

Place visual cues (eg, signs, red arrows) near doorways

Hand hygiene (cleansing and disinfecting hands with soap or antiseptic hand rub) can reduce incidence of preventable, hospital-associated infections (HAI) by up to 70%.  However, despite the significant evidence base supporting this intervention, physician adherence to recommended hand hygiene protocols often remains low.

Low adherence to well-established, evidence-based protocols can arise from suboptimal organizational and systems factors.  Systems interventions are often prioritized as first steps.  This hospital has already attempted multiple recommended systems interventions, including:

  • Optimizing the physical environment (eg, installing additional hand hygiene stations)
  • Ensuring staff knowledge and preparation (eg, holding training sessions)
  • Engaging staff in organizational improvement (eg, collecting staff input on designing interventions)
  • Installing a transparent monitoring system (eg, informing staff that hand hygiene is regularly monitored and tracked)

Despite this, suboptimal hand hygiene rates persist.

In certain situations where systems changes are insufficient, strengthening the organizational culture to promote individual accountability (known as "just culture") is useful.  Examples of accountability-building interventions include incorporating hand hygiene compliance into physician evaluations and enforcing disciplinary measures when repeated hand hygiene transgressions occur (ie, warning note, remedial training).  Such measures should be pursued only after a sustained, comprehensive systems reform that incorporates staff input.

(Choice A)  Cognitive bias (ie, mental shortcuts used to facilitate efficient clinical decision-making in complex settings) can cause diagnostic errors (eg, delayed diagnosis); it is not typically implicated in simple safety action such as handwashing.

(Choice C)  Health care providers generally are aware of the importance of hand hygiene, and this organization has already provided extensive training.  Persistent suboptimal adherence to guidelines suggests the need to address individual accountability.

(Choice D)  Although teamwork training and optimizing communication are recommended to reduce medical errors, handwashing is an individual action and is commonly performed when team members are absent.  Therefore, promoting individual accountability is required.

Educational objective:
Adherence to recommended hand hygiene protocols remains low in most hospital settings.  Suboptimal adherence that persists despite recommended systems changes (eg, increasing the number of hand hygiene stations) suggests the need to improve organizational culture and individual accountability.

questionList.questionText: A 72-year-old woman comes to the office with her daughter for an annual examination.  The daughter says that her mother has seemed increasingly unsteady over the past year.  She fell 2 months ago while getting up in the night to use the bathroom.  The patient has a history of mild cognitive impairment and atrial fibrillation and has been taking an anticoagulant medication for several years.  She lives alone in a single-story home; her daughter helps with meals and shopping.  Vital signs are normal without orthostasis.  BMI is 22 kg/m2.  The patient is fully oriented and remembers 2 of 3 objects after 5 minutes.  Visual acuity is 20/40 bilaterally; motor strength is mildly decreased throughout.  The patient requires extended time to rise from a chair; gait is slow without ataxia.  The remainder of the examination is normal.  Blood testing shows no abnormalities.  The physician discusses fall prevention measures and arranges a home safety assessment.  The patient's daughter expresses concern because her maternal uncle died due to complications following a fall and asks if anything can reduce the risk of injury in case her mother falls again.  Which of the following additional interventions is most effective in reducing the risk of serious fall-related injury in this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Falls in older adults

Overview

  • Leading cause of injury, morbidity, mortality

Risk factors

  • History of fall
  • Sensory & cognitive disturbance
  • Chronic disease (eg, T2DM, arthritis, CVD)
  • Medications (eg, neuroleptics, antidepressants, vasodilators)

Outpatient prevention

  • Screening: musculoskeletal (eg, "get up & go" test*), vision, hearing, bone density, orthostasis
  • Medication & home safety review
  • Correction of vitamin D deficiency (in select patients)
  • Supervised exercise program

Inpatient prevention

  • Assess fall risk & customize strategies to patient's specific risk factors
  • Optimize environment (eg, minimize furniture, lower the bed, place in direct view of nurses if high risk)
  • Perform frequent checks on high-risk patients
  • Avoid restraints & overreliance on fall alert systems

*Ask the patient to rise from a chair & walk briskly to the end of the room.  Time & patient difficulty in this test predict the risk of falling.

CVD = cardiovascular disease; T2DM = type 2 diabetes mellitus.

Falls are a major cause of injury in older adults and can result in trauma, prolonged immobilization, and functional decline.  This patient has multiple fall risk factors, including a prior fall, cognitive impairment, motor weakness, and postural instability (eg, slow gait, prolonged time to rise from a chair).

Despite implementation of primary prevention strategies (eg, exercise training, home safety assessment), patients may still experience falls.  Osteoporosis screening and management (eg, optimization of bone density) have demonstrated effectiveness in preventing secondary fall complications (eg, hip fracture).  Screening measures should include a clinical risk factor assessment (eg, Fracture Risk Assessment Tool [FRAX]) and bone density measurement (eg, dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry).  Treatment (eg, bisphosphonate therapy) is recommended when 10-year fracture risk exceeds 2.5%.

(Choice B)  Risk of falls is not a contraindication to anticoagulation for atrial fibrillation because the risk of serious fall-related head injury (eg, subdural hematoma) is relatively low compared to the risk of stroke and is outweighed by the benefits of stroke prevention.

(Choice C)  Patients who fall and spend a prolonged time on the floor because they are unable to rise experience worse outcomes from a fall.  However, call alarm systems are not effective in reducing fall complications, likely because patients with more serious injuries are unable to access their devices (eg, loss of consciousness, limb injury).

(Choice D)  Hip protectors are wearable devices that contain padding designed to cushion impact and prevent fracture.  However, in multiple studies, no decrease in the risk of fracture has been shown, likely due to low adherence.  Similarly, assistive devices such as canes and walkers encourage mobility of patients with a fear of falling but can be associated with an increased risk of falling and fall-related injury (ie, due to falling onto the device).

Educational objective:
Falls are a major source of injury in older patients.  In addition to primary prevention strategies (eg, supervised exercise, home safety assessment), patients at high risk for falls should be screened for osteoporosis (with treatment as appropriate) to reduce the risk of fracture.

Use of a wearable hip protector at all times

After administrators of an intensive care unit learn that central line–associated bloodstream infections are occurring in their unit at a higher-than-average rate, a committee designs a quality improvement intervention to improve safety of central line insertion procedures.  The intervention includes implementation of a standardized checklist covering all recommended infection control steps for sterile technique in central line insertion.  Prior to implementation, clinicians receive comprehensive training on completing all steps of the checklist.  The committee selects various indicators to assess performance, which are measured at the start of the intervention and 6 months following implementation.  Results are presented below:

Indicator

Change at 6 months

Clinician knowledge of sterile technique protocols

Increased

Average number of central lines placed per month

Unchanged

Average time needed by physicians to document central line placement

Increased

Percentage of patients in the intensive care unit who developed central line–associated infections

Unchanged

Analysis of which of the following indicators is required to better understand these results?
questionList.explanationText:
Indicators used in quality measurement

Structural
indicators

  • Measure organizational structures, including human resources
  • Examples: nurse/patient ratio, clinician knowledge

Process
indicators

  • Measure health care worker compliance with a process, assess performance, detect variations
  • Example: percentage of eligible patients screened for colon cancer

Outcome
indicators

  • Measure changes in health status or outcomes
  • Examples: blood pressure, mortality rate, nosocomial infection rate

Balancing
indicators

  • Measure tradeoffs incurred as a result of systems change
  • Example: increased documentation time after implementing a new safety protocol

Comprehensive measurement is necessary to understand the impact of a quality improvement intervention or systems change.  Using a variety of indicators enables a thorough assessment of the performance of the intervention and can help identify reasons for suboptimal change in outcomes.

This quality improvement intervention included implementation of a checklist intended to reduce the incidence of central line–associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI).  The results table illustrates the following 3 indicator types:

  • Structural measures, which measure organizational capacity, including clinician knowledge regarding sterile technique (which improved) and average number of central lines placed per month (which remained unchanged)

  • Balancing measures, which measure counterbalancing system costs, including average physician documentation time (which increased)

  • Outcome measures, which measure changes in health status, including percentage of patients who develop CLABSI (which remained unchanged)

However, the table does not show process indicators, a fourth type of indicator typically used to measure process variation or compliance (eg, percentage of steps in the checklist completed by clinicians).

To fully understand suboptimal intervention results (ie, unchanged CLABSI incidence in this unit), process indicators would be helpful.  The unit's failure to achieve lower rates of CLABSI could be due to low compliance (eg, the checklist was only partially completed during busy times) or high variation (eg, the checklist was completed differently on different days).  Such findings could identify the likely reasons for the poor results (eg, excessive checklist complexity, insufficient staffing).

(Choices A and B)  Structural and balancing measures have already been measured; further analysis in these indicator types is less useful compared to investigating process measures.

(Choice C)  Patient-related factors (eg, patient age, severity of illness) can affect infection rates; however, such factors are less likely to systematically alter intervention results.  Process measures (eg, consistency of checklist implementation) should be explored first.

Educational objective:
Accurate quality measurement includes measures that assess organizational capacity (structural measures), compliance of health care workers with specified processes (process measures), health status indicators (outcome measures), and counterbalancing costs (balancing measures).

questionList.questionText: A hospital quality-assurance committee reviews data indicating a high prevalence of health care–associated infections caused by drug-resistant enteric pathogens within the hospital; these include diarrheal illnesses, pneumonia, and urinary tract infections.  Although the hospital has established standardized guidelines to prevent infection transmission that incorporate isolation precautions and hand hygiene, committee members are concerned about suboptimal adherence by health care workers.  Which of the following actions is most effective in improving staff adherence to recommended infection-control practices?
questionList.explanationText:
Infection control: isolation precautions

Type

Pathogen*

Key requirements

Airborne

  • Bacterial: tuberculosis
  • Viral: primary VZV (chickenpox), disseminated VZV reactivation (shingles/zoster), dermatomal VZV reactivation (shingles/zoster) in immunocompromised patients, COVID-19, measles
  • Negative pressure room
  • N95 respirator

Contact

  • Multidrug-resistant organism (eg, MRSA, VRE, ESBL producing)
  • Bacterial: Clostridioides difficile, Escherichia coli O157:H7
  • Viral: RSV, primary VZV (chickenpox), disseminated VZV reactivation (shingles/zoster), dermatomal VZV reactivation (shingles/zoster) in immunocompromised patients
  • Gloves & gowns
  • Single-use equipment (eg, stethoscope)

Droplet

  • Bacterial: Neisseria meningitidis, Haemophilus influenzae type B, Mycoplasma pneumoniae
  • Viral: influenza virus, adenovirus
  • Mask within 1-2 m (3-6 ft) of patient

Standard

  • Followed for all patients even when no infection is apparent
  • Hand hygiene
  • Gowns/gloves/masks when appropriate (eg, during procedures)

*Precaution is started immediately when infection with pathogen is suspected.

COVID-19 = coronavirus disease 2019; ESBL = extended-spectrum beta-lactamase; MRSA = methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus; RSV = respiratory syncytial virus; VRE = vancomycin-resistant Enterococcus; VZV = varicella-zoster virus.

Isolation precautions, including contact, airborne, and droplet isolation, are essential to preventing health care–associated infections in the hospital setting.  However, suboptimal compliance with these protocols can occur in busy, complex settings (eg, high patient volume, multiple demands on health care workers' time), compromising patient safety.

According to principles of human factors engineering, processes should be designed to minimize human effort required for correct action (eg, adherence).  Visual aids, such as signs on patient doors specifying isolation precautions, can increase adherence by doing the following:

  • Optimizing environmental design (eg, sign outside patient's room conveys relevant information to health care worker immediately prior to patient contact)

  • Reducing reliance on memory (eg, sign specifies instructions needed for the protocol)

  • Increasing attention through strategically placed alerts (eg, signs are brightly colored and placed selectively only where needed)

(Choice A)  Although patients should be encouraged to be involved in their care and advocate for their safety, isolation precautions should be initiated before health care workers enter the room.  Moreover, patient illness or clinical status (eg, altered mental status) may compromise the patient's ability to recall specific requirements of isolation protocols and communicate in detail with health care providers.

(Choices C and E)  Strategic placement of hand hygiene stations (eg, alcohol-based hand sanitizer) and other equipment (eg, masks, gowns, gloves) is necessary for optimal staff adherence.  However, placing this equipment outside each patient room, where it is intended to be used, is more effective than placing items at computer workstations or in a single location.

(Choice D)  Compared to strategies that optimize the design of processes and environment, education and training is a more passive and less effective strategy in changing human actions.

Educational objective:
Systems should be designed to minimize the effort required for safe action by health care workers.  Adherence to isolation precautions can be increased through strategically placed visual aids (eg, brightly colored signs outside patient doors), which increase attention and reduce reliance on memory.

answerChoiceList.choice: Encouraging patients to ask providers if they are adhering to recommended isolation protocols
Hanging brightly colored signs outside patient rooms specifying isolation precaution type and instructions
Installing dispensers of alcohol-based disinfectant solution near all computer workstations
Providing repeated, mandatory interprofessional training until infection rates decrease
Stocking a supply of gowns, gloves, and masks in a single prominent location on each hospital floor

questionList.questionText: A 43-year-old Vietnamese-speaking woman comes to a busy primary care clinic due to back pain.  She is accompanied by her 14-year-old son, who speaks English.  The physician does not speak Vietnamese.  He uses a videoconference system to reach a certified Vietnamese interpreter, who then translates the physician's words into Vietnamese and the patient's words into English.  The physician diagnoses the patient with lumbosacral back strain, prescribes a 15-day course of naproxen, and counsels the patient on how to use the medication.  The patient states "yes" in her native language when asked whether she has understood this information.  Which of the following actions by the physician is most likely to result in the patient using the medication as counseled?
questionList.explanationText:
Patients with limited English proficiency (LEP) are more likely to experience severe harm from medication errors.  Medication reconciliation (eg, verifying new and existing patient prescriptions; including duration, dose, and frequency) is a high-risk process that relies on adequate patient-physician communication.  Best practices to reduce errors and promote correct patient use of medications include:

  • Use qualified medical interpreters, either trained staff (ie, with training in interpreter ethics, skills, and medical terminology) or videoconference or telephonic systems.  To optimize patient comfort and communication, providers should directly address the patient rather than the interpreter, maintain frequent eye contact with the patient, and speak in short sentences to allow for accurate translation (Choice A).

  • Provide translated written materials (eg, discharge or appointment summary) directly to patients when possible; such materials should accompany (ie, not substitute for) active patient counseling.  Having bilingual family members translate English materials is not recommended due to potential for error; minor children should not be asked to interpret or translate in non-emergency situations (Choice E).

  • Use patient teach-back, in which patients describe their understanding of a treatment plan to the provider (eg, asking this patient to describe how she will take her new medication).  This technique confirms patient understanding and allows clarification of miscommunicated information.  Patients who participate in teach-back are more likely to use medications as prescribed and experience fewer medication errors.

(Choice B)  Although asking the interpreter to repeat instructions emphasizes the new information, teach-back is a superior method to confirm understanding and engage patients; it is more likely to result in the patient using the medication as prescribed.

(Choice C)  When patients are competent and independent, directly engaging the patient is preferred over relying on family members, especially in this case where the patient's son is a minor.

Educational objective:
Patients with limited English proficiency are at increased risk of experiencing serious errors during medication reconciliation (process of verifying new and existing prescriptions).  To reduce errors, physicians should use a qualified interpreter, communicate directly with the patient (rather than only addressing the interpreter), and apply teach-back (eg, asking patients to repeat their understanding of new information, such as new medication instructions).

answerChoiceList.choice: Directly asking the interpreter to assess whether the patient has any concerns about the medication
Directly asking the interpreter to repeat medication instructions slowly to the patient
Directly asking the patient via the interpreter if her son can assist her in taking the medication
Directly asking the patient via the interpreter to describe how she will take the medication
Providing a printed copy of the appointment summary and instructions to the patient's son
